results.title: The Woman Suffers
results.creator_credit: Raymond Longford and National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: This 1918 Australian feature is one of the most significant surviving treasures of a silent film heritage which is now largely extinct. The story takes the concept of primitive justice - an eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth - and extends it to a sister for a sister. Ralph Manton discovers that his sister Marjory has been seduced and demands to be told the name of the man. Faithful to her lover, she refuses, but later Ralph discovers his identity and confronts him. The tables are turned. Starring Australia’s first film star, Lottie Lyell, the film was a critical and commercial success and offered audiences more than just a melodrama. It questioned the social mores of the day and the double standards of morality in regard to the men as the seducers. Musical accompaniment is by members of the Canberra Symphony Orchestra, conducted by composer Donald Hollier.

results.title: The Getting of Wisdom
results.creator_credit: Bruce Beresford, Phillip Adams, Australian Film Commission and Southern Cross Film Productions
results.brief_description: Laura Tweedle Ramsbotham is about to enter another world. From her home in sleepy, rural Australia she ascends to the dreaming spires of an exclusive college for young ladies, a very strict Victorian boarding school in Melbourne. Laura (Susannah Fowles) is strong willed and rebellious, which creates conflict with her peers and her teachers. In a desperate attempt to find acceptance with her peers, she weaves the most lurid yarns imaginable. The only real soulmate she finds is one of the senior girls. The novel by Henry Handel Richardson was published in 1910, and was so shocking at the time that the author’s name (Ethel Richardson) was stricken from the records of the school in which she set the thinly-disguised autobiography. An amusing and sometimes touching story which features an excellent performance from Barry Humphries as the repressed fire and brimstone minister. Also stars John Waters, Sheila Helpman, Patricia Kennedy and Julie Blake.

results.title: Don's Party
results.creator_credit: Bruce Beresford, Phillip Adams and Art House Productions
results.brief_description: Bruce Beresford’s classic Australian comedy exposes Australian social mores in the suburbs. Don and Kath have invited a group of friends to celebrate what they believe will be a Labor Party victory on Election night. The night begins happily enough until the guests receive the news that Labor is losing. Old enmities erupt as hostilities break out amongst the guests as the party disintegrates into an alcoholic disaster. Cast includes Ray Barrett, Graham Kennedy, John Hargreaves, Graeme Blundell, Jeanie Drynan and Clare Binney.

results.title: Rats in the Ranks
results.creator_credit: Robin Anderson, Bob Connolly, Arundel Productions, Film Australia and National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: A behind-the-scenes look at political manoeuvering during the Mayoral elections for the Leichardt Council. Incumbent Larry Hand, while popular with the voters is not so popular with the Council.

constellations_other.name: Bob Connolly
constellations_other.description: Australian audiences just can't seem to get enough of exploring local governments, bureaucracy and politics, whether that's through documentaries or biting social satire.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Robin Anderson, Bob Connolly, Arundel Productions, Film Australia and National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.description: A behind-the-scenes look at political manoeuvering during the Mayoral elections for the Leichardt Council. Incumbent Larry Hand, while popular with the voters is not so popular with the Council. In the Mayoral elections, the Council not the citizens vote, so Hand and his opposition engage in a battle of political tactics including calling in favours, backstabbing and media leaks. Gripping real-life drama with a knuckle-biting climax.

results.title: Doc: a Portrait of Herbert Vere Evatt, 1894-1965
results.creator_credit: Pat Fiske, David McKnight, Denise Haslem, Film Australia and National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: Known as “the Doc”, Evatt was an idealist, internationalist, a lawyer and a politician. He was the only Australian elected as President of the United Nations (1948) and the decisions he handed down as a High Court Judge had lasting effects on the course of Australian political history. Evatt fought to defeat an attempt to ban the Communist Party, only to find that his own party, the Australian Labor Party was deeply divided on the issue and his contentious role in 1950’s politics overshadows his many notable achievements. This excellent documentary blends commentary, newsreel footage and interviews with historians, family and public figures to offer a rare and moving insight into the life of one of Australia’s most notable political figures.

results.title: Large as life: an interview with Pat Thompson
results.creator_credit: Charlotte Seymour and Women's Program of the AFC
results.brief_description: Pat Thompson, one of Australia’s most dynamic and entertaining jazz singers, is interviewed about her life and the resumption of her career after an absence of 34 years.

results.title: Father
results.creator_credit: John Power, Damien Parer, Leftbank Productions and Barron Films
results.brief_description: Internationally renowned Max von Sydow heads a cast of acclaimed actors, including Carol Drinkwater, Julia Blake and Steve Jacobs, in this powerfully moving film. It tells the story of a family whose lives are shattered when their elderly father is accused of being a Nazi war criminal. Torn between family love and loyalty and the devastating realities of wartime Nazi Germany, all relationships are tested to the limit. Photography by Dan Burstall. AFI Awards were won by Max von Sydow and Julia Blake.

results.title: BabaKiueria
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Atherden, Don Featherstone, Julian Pringle and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
‘BabaKiueria’ takes a satirical look at black-white relations in late twentieth century Australia, with a comic depiction of a racial role reversal. In documentary (or ‘mockumentary’) style, the film’s presenter investigates white lives in the fictitious land of ‘BabaKiueria’ (‘Barbeque Area’), where white people are a minority, living under black laws and suffering from discriminatory practices and attitudes held by the black majority. Written by Geoffrey Atherden (‘Mother and Son’, ‘Grass Roots’), the film was awarded a United Nations Media Peace Prize in 1987.
Stars Michelle Torres, Bob Maza, Kevin Smith, Cecily Polson, Tony Barry.

results.title: Crocodile Dundee
results.creator_credit: Peter Faiman, John Cornell, Rimfire Films, Hoyts and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: A New York reporter is intrigued by stories of an Australian crocodile hunter, Mick ‘Crocodile’ Dundee, and accompanies him on a journey through the bush. She entices him back to Manhattan where his easy-going approach to the dangers of life in a big city make him a success in New York society. Stars Paul Hogan and Linda Kozlowski.
